The solution we developed uses ‚Äúsecret sharing.‚Äù Each device has a long-lived secret, but instead of broadcasting that, it broadcasts a ‚Äúshare‚Äù of its secret every few minutes. If any receiver obtains a sufficient number of shares, they can put them together and detect the tag.

Hence what we need is an algorithm that can recover a secret from its shares, in the presence of many unrelated ‚Äúnoise‚Äù shares sent by other devices with different secrets. This could involve hundreds of legitimate shares and thousands of unrelated (innocent) shares.

While this idea seems simple, the challenge is that there are a lot of AirTags in the world! The broadcasts of unrelated ‚Äúbystander‚Äù AirTags can‚Äôt be distinguished from the broadcasts of a stalker. (Indeed if you could distinguish them easily, it would allow tracking.) https://t.co/s72YHAeg7i

The neat thing about secret sharing is that, to anyone who receives too few shares ‚Äî ie, you don‚Äôt spend hours standing next to them with your tag ‚Äî the shares look like random numbers. A stalking victim, by definition, gets lots of shares. People tracking you likely will not.

To fight this, Apple introduced a feature that allows your phone to detect if someone else‚Äôs AirTag is ‚Äúmoving with you.‚Äù

But this posed a conundrum: if AirTags routinely change their identifier to preserve privacy, how can your phone detect that the same AirTag is stalking you? https://t.co/F6G0Oo4NHf

This is a tough problem, because the goal of a ‚Äútracking adversary‚Äù is almost the same as the goal of a potential stalking victim. They both want to link together the broadcasts of a single AirTag. Only one is a ‚Äúbad guy‚Äù and one is a ‚Äúgood guy‚Äù.

So the question we set out to investigate is: can you have devices that change their identifiers constantly (every 15 minutes or even faster) to ensure privacy against unwanted tracking, but still allow victims to detect stalker tags?
